measured_by: Single-item Likert agreement rating: “The defendant seems dangerous” (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree)
justification: In Study 1 participants "rated their agreement with four statements …: The defendant seems dangerous…" indicating this item was the instrument for assessing how dangerous the defendant was judged to be.

measured_by: Single-item Likert agreement rating: “The defendant is likely guilty”
justification: The method section states that participants evaluated each case by rating agreement with the statement "the defendant is likely guilty," showing this item operationalized perceived guilt.

topic_or_construct: Perceived sufficiency of evidence to go to trial
measured_by: Single-item Likert agreement rating: “There is enough evidence to go to trial”
justification: Participants also rated the statement "there is enough evidence to go to trial," which served as the measure of perceived evidentiary sufficiency.

measured_by: Single-item Likert agreement rating: “The prosecutor would have a good case”
justification: The fourth statement participants judged was "the prosecutor would have a good case," used to quantify perceptions of prosecutorial case strength.

measured_by: Single-item Likert agreement rating: “The prisoner does not seem reformed”
justification: In Study 2, while assessing parole cases, participants rated agreement with "The prisoner does not seem reformed," making this item the measure of perceived reformation.

measured_by: Single-item Likert agreement rating: “The prisoner would be a threat to society”
justification: Study 2 instructions list the item "the prisoner would be a threat to society" as one of the four ratings, capturing perceived societal threat.

measured_by: Single-item Likert agreement rating: “The prisoner does not seem repentant”
justification: Participants also rated agreement with "The prisoner does not seem repentant," which operationalized perceived repentance.

measured_by: Single-item Likert agreement rating: “The board should not grant parole”
justification: The fourth parole-related item was "the board should not grant parole," directly measuring the judgment about granting parole.
